categories.name: Pasta & Beyond: The Carbohydrates of Italy

questions.clue: This type of pasta, popular worldwide, is often served with meatballs and marinara sauce.
Shaped like a small ear, this pasta's name comes from the Italian word for 'little ear'.
A traditional dish from Rome, this pasta combines eggs, cheese, pancetta, and pepper.
Known for its ridged edges, this pasta is ideal for capturing hearty sauces in Northern Italy.
Native to the Emilia-Romagna region, this pasta is typically stuffed with a mixture of meat, cheese, and sometimes spinach.

categories.name: Ancient Civilizations: Echoes from the Past

questions.clue: This ancient civilization, known for its pyramids, flourished along the Nile.
Spaghetti may have ancient origins, but this early civilization is credited with the invention of pasta dough.
Before becoming an empire, this early Italian civilization gave us the Latin language and contributions in architecture.
This ancient civilization's capital was known for the Hanging Gardens, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
This civilization, known for its advanced plumbing and urban planning, thrived in the Indus Valley before disappearing mysteriously.

categories.name: The Science of Sound: Acoustics & Beyond

questions.clue: Acoustics is the science of this phenomenon, which describes how sound travels through different mediums.
String instruments like guitars produce sound through the vibration of these, which can vary in thickness and tension.
This culinary-sounding term in acoustics refers to the ratio of sound pressure relative to a reference level, measured in decibels.
Named after an Italian inventor, this effect describes the apparent change in frequency of a sound as the source moves relative to the observer.
This acoustic phenomenon, often managed by architects, involves sound waves bouncing off surfaces, affecting how the sound is heard within a room.

categories.name: Great Works of Art: A Closer Look

questions.clue: This masterpiece by Leonardo da Vinci is famous for its subject's enigmatic smile.
In Raphael's famous fresco 'The School of Athens,' this ancient Greek philosopher is depicted gesturing to the heavens.
Known for a dramatic play of light and shadow, this Caravaggio painting depicts the conversion of its titular saint.
Michelangelo's sculpture of a biblical hero ready to take on Goliath is crafted from a single piece of marble.
Title reflective of a popular color, this painting by Titian shows a seated woman provocatively gazing at the observer.

categories.name: Exploring the Cosmos: From Planets to Galaxies

questions.clue: This planet, known for its extensive ring system, is also the second largest in our solar system.
A long, thin structure like this Italian noodle, the Milky Way is a type of this galaxy characterized by its spiral arms.
Like fettuccine and linguine belong to Italian cuisine, this dwarf planet shares its name with the Roman god of the underworld.
Beyond our galaxy lies this group of galaxies named after the virgin goddess, including many rich, starchy star systems.
Just as Rome is known for its food, this type of galaxy boasts a 'central bulge' and 'dislike' of arms, seen in older, elliptical structures.

final.clue: Named for its resemblance to a specific cut of fabric, this pasta's name means "little ribbons" and pairs perfectly with sauces like Alfredo.
